Class ec.e.inspect.ObjectInspector 

java.lang.Object
   |
   +----ec.e.inspect.Inspector
           |
           +----ec.e.inspect.ObjectInspector
public class ObjectInspector
extends Inspector
An ObjectInspector knows how to inspect Bona Fide Objects. It *can* be used to inspect Hashtables, Strings, Vectors and other special-cased objects but normally we want to use special inspectors for these - A good example is hashtables where we want to see key-value pairs in an array, and are not interested in seeing empty slots in an oversized array.

Arrays of all kinds are inspected using ArryInspector's - An ObjectInspector cannot inspect Arrays at all.

getNumberFields in class Inspector
getInheritedNumberFields 
  public int[] getInheritedNumberFields()
Return an array of int that enumerates how many instance variables are visible at each level of the class inheritance chain when using this opener. Level 0 (at index 0) is the current class.
Overrides:
getInheritedNumberFields in class Inspector
getInheritedClassName 
  public String getInheritedClassName(int superLevel)
Return the class name for the nth superclass. This method never returns "object". We are quite happy about that since normally we don't want to display "Object" - it has no instance variables and would just add a gratuituous top level to our class displays.
Parameters:
superlevel - - The level of superclass we wat the name for. 0 returns the name of the current class, 1 that of its immediate superclass (if any) etc.
getName 
  public String getName(int fieldIndex) throws ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
Return the variable name of a field. Invent a last-resort answer of style "" in case something is wrong with the commentary.
Parameters:
fieldIndex - - an index used to identify the wanted instance variable slot.

Return the declared signatures for a field
Overrides:
getDeclaredSignature in class Inspector
getAssignedSignature 
  public String getAssignedSignature(int fieldIndex) throws ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
Return the signature of the actually assigned data in a field. Note that this may differ from the declared signature in some cases, like if a field is declared a reference to some class of object and it has been assigned an object of some subclass thereof, or if the value is null (which returns the pseudo-signature "N").
Parameters:
fieldIndex - - an index used to identify the wanted instance variable slot.
Overrides:
getAssignedSignature in class Inspector
get 
  public Object get(int fieldIndex) throws ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
Return the value of a field, given a field index. Returns a reference data type. Primitive data types will be wrapped.
Parameters:
fieldIndex - - The index of the local variable field according to the used opener, or the index of the element if the object being inspected is an array.
Overrides:
get in class Inspector
set 
  public void set(int fieldIndex,
                  Object newValue) throws ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
Set the value of a field, given a field index, a new value. Only works for reference data types - primitive data types should be wrapped.
Parameters:
fieldIndex - - The index of the local variable field according to the used opener, or the index of the element if the object being inspected is an array.
newValue - nullOK, trusted - The new value to assign to the instance variable. Note that this value is marked as "trusted" - The inspector itself is not assuming the value to be trusted but since we are adding the reference to another arbitrary inspected object we are in fact relaying the reference and all capabilities it embodies to the receiving object. Note: Guaranteeing that we can maintain our capability semantics under *inspection* is quite a daunting task. Certainly the matter of trusted/untruste for newValue here is of no consequence until we commonly use non-Surgeon openers.
Overrides:
set in class Inspector
